message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) is more reliable than balanced accuracy, bookmaker informedness, and markedness in two-class confusion matrix evaluation
Paper Abstract: Abstract Evaluating binary classifications is a pivotal task in statistics and machine learning, because it can influence decisions in multiple areas, including for example prognosis or therapies of patients in critical conditions. The scientific community has not agreed on a general-purpose statistical indicator for evaluating two-class confusion matrices (having true positives, true negatives, false positives, and false negatives) yet, even if advantages of the Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) over accuracy and F 1 score have already been shown.In this manuscript, we reaffirm that MCC is a robust metric that summarizes the classifier performance in a single value, if positive and negative cases are of equal importance. We compare MCC to other metrics which value positive and negative cases equally: balanced accuracy (BA), bookmaker informedness (BM), and markedness (MK). We explain the mathematical relationships between MCC and these indicators, then show some use cases and a bioinformatics scenario where these metrics disagree and where MCC generates a more informative response.Additionally, we describe three exceptions where BM can be more appropriate: analyzing classifications where dataset prevalence is unrepresentative, comparing classifiers on different datasets, and assessing the random guessing level of a classifier. Except in these cases, we believe that MCC is the most informative among the single metrics discussed, and suggest it as standard measure for scientists of all fields. A Matthews correlation coefficient close to +1, in fact, means having high values for all the other confusion matrix metrics. The same cannot be said for balanced accuracy, markedness, bookmaker informedness, accuracy and F 1 score.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Balanced accuracy"

Links: [{"title":"Precision and recall - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Precision_and_recall"},{"title":"Evaluation of binary classifiers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evaluation_of_binary_classifiers"},{"title":"Confusion matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confusion_matrix"},{"title":"Phi coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthews_correlation_coefficient"},{"title":"The Fiscal Times - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Fiscal_Times"},{"title":"Seitengewehr 98 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seitengewehr_98"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about balanced accuracy:

## Balanced Accuracy

Balanced accuracy (bACC) normalizes true positive and true negative predictions by the number of positive and negative samples, respectively, and divides their sum by two.

### Why It's Used

Accuracy will yield misleading results if the data set is unbalanced; that is, when the numbers of observations in different classes vary greatly. Balanced accuracy addresses this problem by treating both positive and negative classes equally, regardless of their actual prevalence in the dataset.

### When It Matters

This metric is particularly useful in scenarios where a classifier might classify all observations as having the majority class, resulting in high overall accuracy while performing poorly on the minority class. Balanced accuracy provides a more reliable assessment in such imbalanced classification scenarios.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC)

The Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) is a measure of the quality of binary (two-class) classifications, widely used in machine learning and bioinformatics.

### Key Characteristics

The MCC is a correlation coefficient between the observed and predicted binary classifications; it returns a value between −1 and +1, where a coefficient of +1 represents a perfect prediction, 0 indicates random prediction, and −1 indicates total disagreement between prediction and observation.

### Advantages

The coefficient accounts for true and false positives and negatives and is generally regarded as a balanced measure which can be used even if the classes are of very different sizes. This is particularly valuable because the Matthews correlation coefficient is generally regarded as being one of the best measures of a confusion matrix, while other measures such as accuracy are not useful when the two classes are of very different sizes.

### Historical Context

The Matthews correlation coefficient was coined in 1975 by the eponymous biochemist and is actually equivalent to the Pearson/Boas-Yule phi coefficient.

### Related Metrics

Measures such as the phi coefficient, Matthews correlation coefficient, informedness, or Cohen's kappa may be preferable to assess the performance of a binary classifier. The MCC is particularly recommended when evaluating classification performance on imbalanced datasets.

Web search results for query: "Confusion matrix"

Links: [{"title":"Confusion matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confusion_matrix"},{"title":"Template talk:Confusion matrix terms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_talk:Confusion_matrix_terms"},{"title":"Matrix equivalence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_equivalence"},{"title":"Polynomial matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynomial_matrix"},{"title":"Talk:Matrix management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Matrix_management"}]

## Confusion Matrix

A confusion matrix, also known as error matrix, is a specific table layout that allows visualization of the performance of an algorithm, typically a supervised learning one.

### Structure and Components

The template for any binary confusion matrix uses the four kinds of results: true positives, false negatives, false positives, and true negatives.(no content)The four outcomes can be formulated in a 2×2 confusion matrix.

### Key Advantages

All correct predictions are located in the diagonal of the table, so it is easy to visually inspect the table for prediction errors, as values outside the diagonal will represent them.(no content)A confusion matrix allows more detailed analysis than simply observing the proportion of correct classifications (accuracy). This is particularly important because accuracy will yield misleading results if the data set is unbalanced; that is, when the numbers of observations in different classes vary greatly.

### Multi-class and Extended Applications

Confusion matrix is not limited to binary classification and can be used in multi-class classifiers as well. Additionally, they can be extended to Multi-label classification (where multiple classes can be predicted at once) and soft-label classification (where classes can be partially present).

## Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms, supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

## Historical Development

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)Within a subdiscipline in machine learning, advances in the field of deep learning have allowed neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.

## Key Technologies

The search results also cover related topics like neural networks, deep learning architectures (including transformers and attention mechanisms), and various learning algorithms that form the foundation of modern machine learning systems.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of binary classification:

## Definition

Binary classification is the task of putting things into one of two categories (each called a class).(no content)It is the simplest form of the general task of classification into any number of classes.

## Machine Learning Context

Statistical classification is a problem studied in machine learning in which the classification is performed on the basis of a classification rule. It is a type of supervised learning, a method of machine learning where the categories are predefined, and is used to categorize new probabilistic observations into said categories.

## Key Examples and Applications

Logistic regression is a supervised machine learning algorithm widely used for binary classification tasks, such as identifying whether an email is spam or not and diagnosing diseases by assessing the presence or absence of specific conditions based on patient test results.

## Evaluation Metrics

There are four basic combinations of actual data category and assigned category: true positives TP (correct positive assignments), true negatives TN (correct negative assignments), false positives FP (incorrect positive assignments), and false negatives FN (incorrect negative assignments).(no content)In medicine sensitivity and specificity are often used, while in computer science precision and recall are preferred. Additionally, the F-score or F-measure is a measure of predictive performance calculated from the precision and recall of the test.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of binary classification:

## Definition

Binary classification is the task of putting things into one of two categories (each called a class).(no content)It is the simplest form of the general task of classification into any number of classes.

## Machine Learning Context

Statistical classification is a problem studied in machine learning in which the classification is performed on the basis of a classification rule. It is a type of supervised learning, a method of machine learning where the categories are predefined, and is used to categorize new probabilistic observations into said categories.

## Key Examples and Applications

Logistic regression is a supervised machine learning algorithm widely used for binary classification tasks, such as identifying whether an email is spam or not and diagnosing diseases by assessing the presence or absence of specific conditions based on patient test results.

## Evaluation Metrics

There are four basic combinations of actual data category and assigned category: true positives TP (correct positive assignments), true negatives TN (correct negative assignments), false positives FP (incorrect positive assignments), and false negatives FN (incorrect negative assignments).(no content)In medicine sensitivity and specificity are often used, while in computer science precision and recall are preferred. Additionally, the F-score or F-measure is a measure of predictive performance calculated from the precision and recall of the test.

Links: [{"title":"F-score - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-score"},{"title":"Talk:F-score - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:F1_Score"},{"title":"Precision and recall - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Precision_and_recall"},{"title":"Piotroski F-score - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piotroski_F-Score"},{"title":"Aston Martin in Formula One - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aston_Martin_F1_Team"},{"title":"Phi coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthews_correlation_coefficient"},{"title":"List of Formula One World Championship points scoring systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Championship_points_scoring_systems"},{"title":"Stewart SF02 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stewart_SF02"},{"title":"Tyrrell 023 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrrell_023"},{"title":"Sauber C30 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sauber_C30"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the F1 score:

## Definition

The traditional F-measure or balanced F-score (F1 score) is the harmonic mean of precision and recall. More specifically, the F-measure is calculated as 2 times the product of precision and recall divided by their sum.

## Applications

The F-score is often used in the field of information retrieval for measuring search, document classification, and query classification performance. The F-score is also used in machine learning and has been widely used in the natural language processing literature, such as in the evaluation of named entity recognition and word segmentation.

It is particularly relevant in applications which are primarily concerned with the positive class and where the positive class is rare relative to the negative class.

## Criticisms

David Hand and others criticize the widespread use of the F1 score since it gives equal importance to precision and recall. Additionally, another source of critique of F1 is its lack of symmetry—it may change its value when dataset labeling is changed, with the "positive" samples named "negative" and vice versa.

Web search results for query: "Informedness sensitivity specificity"

Links: [{"title":"Sensitivity and specificity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensitivity_and_specificity"},{"title":"Youden's J statistic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youden's_J_statistic"},{"title":"Positive and negative predictive values - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive_and_negative_predictive_values"},{"title":"Evaluation of binary classifiers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evaluation_of_binary_classifiers"},{"title":"Sensitivity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensitivity"},{"title":"F-score - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-score"},{"title":"Sensitivity analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensitivity_analysis"},{"title":"Talk:Sensitivity and specificity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Sensitivity_and_specificity"},{"title":"Specificity and sensitivity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Specificity_and_sensitivity&redirect=no"},{"title":"Information sensitivity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_sensitivity"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the relationship between informedness, sensitivity, and specificity:

## Informedness Definition

Informedness is calculated as specificity + sensitivity − 1 (or equivalently TPR − FPR), and represents the probability of an informed decision between two classes, where a value greater than 0 represents appropriate use of information, 0 represents chance-level performance, and less than 0 represents perverse use of information.

## Connection to Youden's J Statistic

Youden's J statistic (also called Youden's index) is a single statistic that captures the performance of a dichotomous diagnostic test, calculated as sensitivity + specificity − 1. This is equivalent to the informedness metric.

## Alternative Names

In meteorology, this statistic is referred to as Peirce Skill Score (PSS), Hanssen–Kuipers Discriminant (HKD), or True Skill Statistic (TSS).

## Use in Classifier Evaluation

Informedness (along with measures such as the Matthews correlation coefficient and Cohen's kappa) may be preferred to assess the performance of a binary classifier because F-measures do not take true negatives into account.

In essence, informedness combines sensitivity and specificity into a single metric that measures how well an informed decision can be made with a classifier, accounting for both true positive and true negative rates.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about statistics as a science:

## Definition and Core Purpose

Statistics is the discipline that concerns the collection, organization, analysis, interpretation, and presentation of data.(no content)Statistics is considered the science of uncertainty.

## Historical Background

The word statistics ultimately comes from the Latin word Status, meaning "situation" or "condition" in society, and political scientist Gottfried Achenwall coined the German word statistik (a summary of how things stand).(no content)The modern field of statistics emerged in the late 19th and early 20th century, led by the work of Francis Galton and Karl Pearson, who transformed statistics into a rigorous mathematical discipline used for analysis, not just in science, but in industry and politics as well. Galton's contributions included introducing the concepts of standard deviation, correlation, regression analysis and the application of these methods to the study of the variety of human characteristics.

## Applications

Today, statistics is widely employed in government, business, and natural and social sciences.(no content)Statistics is employed in economics, psychology, political science, sociology and anthropology. Statistics also has specialized applications in fields like biostatistics, environmental statistics, computational statistics, and many others.

## Key Methods

Statistics deals with every aspect of data, including the planning of data collection in terms of the design of surveys and experiments.

## Historical Background

The word statistics ultimately comes from the Latin word Status, meaning "situation" or "condition" in society, and political scientist Gottfried Achenwall coined the German word statistik (a summary of how things stand).(no content)The modern field of statistics emerged in the late 19th and early 20th century, led by the work of Francis Galton and Karl Pearson, who transformed statistics into a rigorous mathematical discipline used for analysis, not just in science, but in industry and politics as well. Galton's contributions included introducing the concepts of standard deviation, correlation, regression analysis and the application of these methods to the study of the variety of human characteristics.

## Applications

Today, statistics is widely employed in government, business, and natural and social sciences.(no content)Statistics is employed in economics, psychology, political science, sociology and anthropology. Statistics also has specialized applications in fields like biostatistics, environmental statistics, computational statistics, and many others.

## Key Methods

Statistics deals with every aspect of data, including the planning of data collection in terms of the design of surveys and experiments.

Links: [{"title":"Precision and recall - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Precision_and_recall"},{"title":"Accuracy and precision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accuracy_and_precision"},{"title":"Accuracy paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accuracy_paradox"},{"title":"Receiver operating characteristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Receiver_operating_characteristic"},{"title":"Machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning"},{"title":"Fairness (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fairness_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Statistical learning theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_learning_theory"},{"title":"Cohen's kappa - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cohen's_kappa"},{"title":"Learning curve (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_curve_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Résumé parsing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resume_parsing"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of accuracy statistics in machine learning:

## Key Accuracy Metrics

In classification and machine learning, precision and recall are performance metrics that apply to data retrieved from a collection, corpus or sample space.(no content)Precision is the fraction of relevant instances among the retrieved instances.(no content)Recall is the fraction of relevant instances that were retrieved.

## Limitations of Accuracy

The accuracy paradox is the paradoxical finding that accuracy is not a good metric for predictive models when classifying in predictive analytics, because a simple model may have a high level of accuracy but too crude to be useful.(no content)Accuracy can be a misleading metric for imbalanced data sets—for example, classifying all values as negative in a sample with 95 negative and 5 positive values gives 0.95 accuracy score.

## Alternative Metrics

Balanced accuracy normalizes true positive and true negative predictions by the number of positive and negative samples, respectively, and divides their sum by two.(no content)Examples of measures that are a combination of precision and recall are the F-measure and the Matthews correlation coefficient.

## Practical Applications

Precision and recall may be useful in cases where there is imbalanced data, and it may be valuable to prioritize one metric over the other in cases where the outcome of a false positive or false negative is costly.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Survey

The paper is classified as a **survey** because it analyzes and compares existing evaluation metrics (Matthews correlation coefficient, balanced accuracy, bookmaker informedness, markedness, accuracy, and F1 score) without proposing a new metric or technique. It acts as a position paper arguing for MCC adoption based on comparative analysis.

**Extracted Triples:** 9 entities identified

The analysis identified 9 key entities from the paper's title and abstract:

1. **Matthews correlation coefficient** - method used for binary classification evaluation
2. **Balanced accuracy** - alternative metric for equal treatment of positive and negative cases
3. **Confusion matrix** - fundamental evaluation framework with TP, TN, FP, FN
4. **F-score** - harmonic mean of precision and recall
5. **Binary classification** - the task domain being evaluated
6. **Machine learning** - the discipline where these metrics are applied
7. **Statistics** - the scientific foundation for these evaluation measures
8. **Accuracy** - baseline metric compared to MCC
9. **Youden's J statistic** - alternative metric equivalent to informedness

All triples have been validated successfully with proper Wikipedia URLs, entity types, relations, and relevance descriptions. The validation confirmed:
- ✅ Paper type correctly set
- ✅ All triples properly formatted
- ✅ Valid Wikipedia URLs
- ✅ Appropriate entity types distribution

Sources:
- [Phi coefficient - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phi_coefficient)
- [Confusion matrix - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confusion_matrix)
- [F-score - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-score)
- [Binary classification - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_classification)
- [Machine learning - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning)
- [Statistics - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistics)
- [Accuracy and precision - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accuracy_and_precision)
- [Youden's J statistic - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Youden's_J_statistic)
